articles.headline: Job Gains Are Waning, a Blow to Economic Recovery
articles.snippet: Payrolls grew last month, but permanent layoffs are rising, the labor force is contracting, and fewer women are employed.
articles.abstract: Payrolls grew last month, but permanent layoffs are rising, the labor force is contracting, and fewer women are employed.
articles.lead_paragraph: Six months after the coronavirus pandemic tore a hole in the U.S. economy, the once-promising recovery is stalling, leaving millions out of work, and threatening to push millions more — particularly women — out of the labor force entirely.
articles.byline: By Ben Casselman and Gillian Friedman

articles.headline: Trump’s Illness Makes It Clear: This Election Was Always About the Virus
articles.snippet: For all of the tumult of the race between President Trump and Joseph R. Biden Jr. — and for all of the other currents battering the country and its leaders in an election year — the issue of the virus has never retreated as the overwhelming factor...
articles.abstract: For all of the tumult of the race between President Trump and Joseph R. Biden Jr. — and for all of the other currents battering the country and its leaders in an election year — the issue of the virus has never retreated as the overwhelming factor.
articles.lead_paragraph: [Watch live VP debate and analysis.]
articles.byline: By Alexander Burns

articles.headline: Led by Tesla, Auto Industry Rebounds as Car Sales Surge
articles.snippet: Tesla reported record deliveries in the third quarter as growing interest in electric vehicles and other cars boosted sales across the industry.
articles.abstract: Tesla reported record deliveries in the third quarter as growing interest in electric vehicles and other cars boosted sales across the industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the coronavirus pandemic forced businesses to close this spring, the auto industry was hit particularly hard. North American auto plants that typically churn out more than a million cars a month produced fewer than 5,000 in April.
articles.byline: By Neal E. Boudette

articles.headline: 74 and Overweight, Trump Faces Extra Risks From ‘a Very Sneaky Virus’
articles.snippet: The president has boasted of his health and is sure to receive the best possible care, but he carries a number of risk factors as he begins his battle with Covid-19.
articles.abstract: The president has boasted of his health and is sure to receive the best possible care, but he carries a number of risk factors as he begins his battle with Covid-19.
articles.lead_paragraph: [Read our live updates on President Trump’s coronavirus diagnosis.]
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg

articles.headline: Trump Hospitalized With Coronavirus
articles.snippet: The president was flown to Walter Reed National Military Medical Center, where officials said he would stay for several days. Aides said Mr. Trump was experiencing coughing, congestion and fever, symptoms that worsened through the day.
articles.abstract: The president was flown to Walter Reed National Military Medical Center, where officials said he would stay for several days. Aides said Mr. Trump was experiencing coughing, congestion and fever, symptoms that worsened through the day.
articles.lead_paragraph: [Read our live updates on President Trump’s coronavirus diagnosis.]
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: The Busy Week When the President Met the Virus
articles.snippet: He disparaged masks, encouraged big campaign crowds and employed an often-unreliable test to keep him safe. All the while it turned out the virus was nearby.
articles.abstract: He disparaged masks, encouraged big campaign crowds and employed an often-unreliable test to keep him safe. All the while it turned out the virus was nearby.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Marine One, its engines roaring, was waiting on the South Lawn of the White House Thursday afternoon when President Trump walked out of the Oval Office, offering a brief wave but skipping his usual verbal combat with reporters.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear, Maggie Haberman and Kenneth P. Vogel

articles.headline: What a $300,000 College Might Cost a $200,000 Family
articles.snippet: More need-based financial aid is available for the affluent than you might expect.
articles.abstract: More need-based financial aid is available for the affluent than you might expect.
articles.lead_paragraph: College is so expensive that even the affluent can be considered needy.
articles.byline: By Ron Lieber

articles.headline: The Short Tenure and Abrupt Ouster of Banking’s Sole Black C.E.O.
articles.snippet: Tidjane Thiam made Credit Suisse profitable again. But the Swiss rejected him as an outsider, and a sudden scandal took him down.
articles.abstract: Tidjane Thiam made Credit Suisse profitable again. But the Swiss rejected him as an outsider, and a sudden scandal took him down.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last November, Urs Rohner, the chairman of the board of Credit Suisse, had a party at a Zurich restaurant to celebrate his 60th birthday. Among the scores of friends, family and business associates who gathered, attendees say, there was a single Black guest: Tidjane Thiam, the bank’s chief executive.
articles.byline: By Kate Kelly

articles.headline: Workers Face Permanent Job Losses as the Virus Persists
articles.snippet: Soon, a wave of people will have been out of work for more than six months, the threshold for long-term unemployment.
articles.abstract: Soon, a wave of people will have been out of work for more than six months, the threshold for long-term unemployment.
articles.lead_paragraph: The United States economy is facing a tidal wave of long-term unemployment as millions of people who lost jobs early in the pandemic remain out of work six months later and job losses increasingly turn permanent.
articles.byline: By Jeanna Smialek, Ben Casselman and Gillian Friedman

articles.headline: A White House Long in Denial Confronts Reality
articles.snippet: The infections were a byproduct, former aides said, of the recklessness and top-down culture of fear that President Trump created at the White House and throughout his administration.
articles.abstract: The infections were a byproduct, former aides said, of the recklessness and top-down culture of fear that President Trump created at the White House and throughout his administration.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As America locked down this spring during the worst pandemic in a century, inside the Trump White House there was the usual defiance.
articles.byline: By Annie Karni and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Trump’s Symptoms Described as ‘Very Concerning’ Even as Doctors Offer Rosier Picture
articles.snippet: The president’s medical team refused to provide critical details and left open the impression that he was known to be sick a day earlier than previously reported, forcing them to backtrack later.
articles.abstract: The president’s medical team refused to provide critical details and left open the impression that he was known to be sick a day earlier than previously reported, forcing them to backtrack later.
articles.lead_paragraph: [Read our live updates on President Trump’s coronavirus diagnosis.]
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: The President’s Illness Is Yet Another Dividing Line in the Trump Era
articles.snippet: In a different moment, a stricken leader might have rallied people behind him. But President Trump’s health crisis is filtered through the partisan lenses that divide Americans on seemingly every issue.
articles.abstract: In a different moment, a stricken leader might have rallied people behind him. But President Trump’s health crisis is filtered through the partisan lenses that divide Americans on seemingly every issue.
articles.lead_paragraph: [Watch live VP debate and analysis.]
articles.byline: By Jennifer Medina and Trip Gabriel

articles.headline: For Trump, the Only Medical News Is Good Medical News
articles.snippet: Conflicting accounts of the president’s condition underline the fact that the public does not have a definitive answer about the president’s health.
articles.abstract: Conflicting accounts of the president’s condition underline the fact that the public does not have a definitive answer about the president’s health.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Dr. Sean P. Conley stepped in front of the cameras at Walter Reed National Military Medical Center on Saturday, he delivered a briefing that seemed intended less to inform the American public than to satisfy the public relations demands of a famous and famously demanding patient — President Trump.
articles.byline: By Annie Karni

articles.headline: A Black Belgian Student Saw a White Fraternity as His Ticket. It Was His Death.
articles.snippet: Sanda Dia’s death after an initiation ritual was regarded as a tragic accident. Newly released videos and photos have made it a symbol of growing intolerance.
articles.abstract: Sanda Dia’s death after an initiation ritual was regarded as a tragic accident. Newly released videos and photos have made it a symbol of growing intolerance.
articles.lead_paragraph: GHENT, Belgium — Sanda Dia saw a fraternity as a doorway into a different life. The son of an immigrant factory worker, he was an ambitious 20-year-old Black student at one of Belgium’s most prestigious universities. The fraternity, Reuzegom, was home to the scions of Antwerp’s white elites.
articles.byline: By Matt Apuzzo and Steven Erlanger

articles.headline: After Biden’s Exposure to Trump, His Team Is Cagey on Health Questions
articles.snippet: With transparency on health newly significant in the presidential race, Joe Biden’s safety protocols have remained largely under wraps. But on Sunday evening, his campaign said he had again tested negative for the coronavirus.
articles.abstract: With transparency on health newly significant in the presidential race, Joe Biden’s safety protocols have remained largely under wraps. But on Sunday evening, his campaign said he had again tested negative for the coronavirus.
articles.lead_paragraph: [Follow our live Biden vs. Trump 2020 election coverage.]
articles.byline: By Thomas Kaplan, Apoorva Mandavilli and Katie Glueck

articles.headline: How to Cover a Sick Old Man
articles.snippet: The president is hospitalized and reporters are fighting for basic facts. What should elderly leaders — many of America’s top politicians are over 80 — reveal about their health?
articles.abstract: The president is hospitalized and reporters are fighting for basic facts. What should elderly leaders — many of America’s top politicians are over 80 — reveal about their health?
articles.lead_paragraph: When John Bresnahan was starting out as a reporter in the mid-1990s, he approached Senator Strom Thurmond of South Carolina, who had run for president in 1948 as a segregationist and was still shuffling through the Capitol. Senator Thurmond, born in 1902, gave no indication that he’d understood Mr. Bresnahan’s question and responded with a non sequitur.
articles.byline: By Ben Smith

articles.headline: As Trump Seeks to Project Strength, Doctors Disclose Alarming Episodes
articles.snippet: The president made a surprise outing from his hospital bed in an effort to show his improvement, but the murky and shifting narrative of his illness was rewritten again with grim new details.
articles.abstract: The president made a surprise outing from his hospital bed in an effort to show his improvement, but the murky and shifting narrative of his illness was rewritten again with grim new details.
articles.lead_paragraph: [Read our live updates on President Trump’s coronavirus diagnosis.]
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: At Afghan Peace Talks, Hoping to End Their Fathers’ War
articles.snippet: The children of the war against the Soviets carry legacies of loss and determination — and their own generation’s crimes — as they meet to try to break a cycle of devastation.
articles.abstract: The children of the war against the Soviets carry legacies of loss and determination — and their own generation’s crimes — as they meet to try to break a cycle of devastation.
articles.lead_paragraph: DOHA, Qatar — They are here to end their fathers’ war.
articles.byline: By Mujib Mashal

articles.headline: The Pence-Harris V.P. Debate Now Has Big Consequences
articles.snippet: Vice-presidential debates can often be afterthoughts in a presidential race. But with President Trump in the hospital, Mike Pence and Kamala Harris will now face an unusual amount of scrutiny, and a tricky balancing act.
articles.abstract: Vice-presidential debates can often be afterthoughts in a presidential race. But with President Trump in the hospital, Mike Pence and Kamala Harris will now face an unusual amount of scrutiny, and a tricky balancing act.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Trump’s hospitalization with the coronavirus has catapulted this week’s vice-presidential debate into the spotlight to an extraordinary degree, putting pressure on Vice President Mike Pence and Senator Kamala Harris to use this forum to reassure an anxious public they are prepared and qualified to step in as president.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney and Shane Goldmacher

articles.headline: ‘I Had Lost All Hope’: Clorox Wipes Are Still the Hard-to-Find Pandemic Item
articles.snippet: For some on social media, finding the cleaning product has become like winning the lottery.
articles.abstract: For some on social media, finding the cleaning product has become like winning the lottery.
articles.lead_paragraph: For six months, May Vanegas hunted her prey.
articles.byline: By Julie Creswell

articles.headline: A Student Dies, and a Campus Gets Serious About Coronavirus
articles.snippet: Cases are spiking at Appalachian State in North Carolina, causing many students and faculty members to call for stronger safety measures.
articles.abstract: Cases are spiking at Appalachian State in North Carolina, causing many students and faculty members to call for stronger safety measures.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOONE, N.C. — Since last Monday, when a sophomore at his school died from suspected Covid-19 complications, Chase Sturgis says he has been thinking about his own bout with the coronavirus — and his own mortality.
articles.byline: By Cristina Bolling and Shawn Hubler

articles.headline: ‘The Coal Industry Is Back,’ Trump Proclaimed. It Wasn’t.
articles.snippet: The demise of coal-fired power plants in Arizona and Kentucky shows how the president, despite promises to restore jobs, failed to counter the forces decimating the industry.
articles.abstract: The demise of coal-fired power plants in Arizona and Kentucky shows how the president, despite promises to restore jobs, failed to counter the forces decimating the industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: PAGE, Ariz. — For decades, waves of electricity poured from this behemoth of a power plant on the high desert plateau of the Navajo reservation in northern Arizona, lighting up hundreds of thousands of homes from Phoenix to Las Vegas as it burned 240 rail cars’ worth of coal a day.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton

articles.headline: Calamities Challenge California’s Economic Foundation
articles.snippet: The pandemic and wildfires have underscored issues of housing and growth. Will the disruptions and dislocations force the state to chart a new course?
articles.abstract: The pandemic and wildfires have underscored issues of housing and growth. Will the disruptions and dislocations force the state to chart a new course?
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Businesses shuttered by the pandemic are slowly reopening, but technology complexes are quiet, their workers carrying on from home indefinitely. The smoke-filled skies had started to clear, but new fires have arrived in a fierce wildfire season that shows the intensifying effects of climate change.
articles.byline: By Conor Dougherty
